title: Thomas Cook passenger is 'stuck' in Tunisia with no cash
text:
Julie Paige booked a flight that was not covered by the industry insurance fund Atol and the date she was due to fly fell outside the government's repatriation scheme

A Thomas Cook passenger says she is 'stuck' in Tunisia following the collapse of the British travel company.

Julie Paige booked a flight that was not covered by the industry insurance fund Atol and the date she was due to fly fell outside the government's repatriation scheme.

The nurse says she cannot afford the £300 needed for a return trip, and said: 'I don't know what to do'.

'I had a flight booked with Thomas Cook to return back to the UK on 8 October which no longer exists,' she told the BBC.

'I'm stuck. I just didn't expect this to happen. I live month to month as a single parent and I have no spare money.'

The Atol protection scheme only covers package holidays, not flight-only bookings.

Meanwhile, Ms Paige's flight on Tuesday falls just outside the two-week period covered by the Civil Aviation Authority's Operation Matterhorn.

Britain's biggest ever peacetime repatriation concluded yesterday, having successfully moved 140,000 Thomas Cook passengers back to the UK.

Responding to Ms Paige's problem, the CAA said people who fell outside the repatriation window should contact their travel insurer, their bank or the Foreign Office.

There was more inconvenience for Thomas Cook customers yesterday when the website set up to help them apply for refunds crashed.

Customers of the bust travel firm received error messages as they attempted to input their flight details into the website.

The nurse says she cannot afford the £300 needed for a return trip, and said: 'I don't know what to do'. Pictured: A file photo of a Thomas Cook plane

The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA), which operates the dedicated website for Thomas Cook customers, apologised and said it had experienced 'unprecedented demand'.

The website went live at 6am Monday and is for people with future Thomas Cook bookings to apply for a refund.

It is now up and running again.
description: Julie Paige booked a flight with the collapsed UK travel firm that was not covered by the industry insurance fund Atol and the date she was due to fly fell outside the CAA's repatriation scheme.
